tit.cmt: 頭文字を大文字に変更

sen.j: 稲飯命(いなひのみこと) 稲氷命 彦稲氷命は日本神話に登場する日本の皇族。
sen.e: He was a member of Japanese Imperial family, who appears in the日本神話Japanese Mythology.
sen.cmt: 名前の表記に漢字を加えました。
sen.e: Inahi no mikoto was a member of Japanese Imperial family, who appears in the Japanese Mythology.
sen.cmt: He→Inahi no mikotoに修正、訳文内の"日本神話"を削除
sen.e: Inahi no mikoto was a member of Japanese Imperial family, who appears in the Japanese Mythology.
In "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), his name was written as (Inahi no mikoto).
In the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), his name was written as 稻飯命 (Inahi no mikoto).
sen.cmt: In the "Nihonshoki"とし、(Inahi no mikoto)の前に漢字表記追加
sen.e: In the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), his name was written as 稻飯命 (Inahi no mikoto).

sen.j: 『古事記』では、稻氷命、彦稲氷命。
sen.e: In "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), his name was written as 稲氷命 or 彦稲氷命 (both of them pronounced as 'Inahi no mikoto,' as well).
sen.cmt: 稲氷命、彦稲氷命→稲氷命 or 彦稲氷命(both of them pronounced as 'Inahi no mikoto,' as well)としました。
sen.e: In the "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), his name was written as 稲氷命 or 彦稲氷命 (both of them pronounced as 'Inahi no mikoto,' as well).
In the "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), his name was written as 稲氷命 or 彦稲氷命 (both of them pronounced as 'Inahi no mikoto,' as well).

sen.j: ウガヤフキアエズ（ウガヤフキアエズ）と海神の娘であるタマヨリビメの二番目の子（第三子とも）。
sen.e: It is also said that he was the second (or the third) son of Ugayafukiaezu (a Japanese deity, the father of Emperor Jinmu) and the daughter of Watatsumi no kami (tutelary of the sea), Princess Tamayoribime.
sen.cmt: タマヨリビメ→Prinecss Tamayoribimeとしました。
sen.e: It is also said that he was the second (or the third) son of Ugayafukiaezu (a Japanese deity, the father of Emperor Jinmu) and the daughter of Watatsumi no kami (tutelary of the sea), Princess Tamayoribime.

It is also said that he was the second (or the third) son of Ugayafukiaezu (a Japanese deity, the father of Emperor Jinmu) and the daughter of Watatsumi no kami (tutelary of the sea), Princess Tamayoribime.

sen.j: 兄に五瀬命、弟に御毛沼命、若御毛沼命（磐余彦尊）がいる。
sen.e: His elder brother was Itsuse no mikoto, and his younger brothers were Mikenu no mikoto and Wakamikenu no mikoto (Iwarehiko no mikoto).
His older brother was Itsuse no mikoto, and his younger brothers were Mikenu no mikoto and Wakamikenu no mikoto (Iwarehiko no mikoto).
sen.cmt: 統一事項よりelder brother→older brotherに修正、全角スペースを半角に修正
sen.e: His older brother was Itsuse no mikoto, and his younger brothers were Mikenu no mikoto and Wakamikenu no mikoto (Iwarehiko no mikoto).

sen.j: 磐余彦尊が後に神武天皇になる。
sen.e: Iwarehiko no Mikoto later became Emperor Jinmu.
Iwarehiko no Mikoto later became Emperor Jinmu.
Iwarehiko no Mikoto later became Emperor Jinmu.

sen.j: 『古事記』では、稲氷命は妣國である海原へ入坐とする。
sen.e: According to the Kojiki, Inahi no mikoto entered into the sea toward Kana no kuni Country, that is to say, toward the ocean.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。 『古事記』→the Kojiki 初出以外はこうしました。
sen.e: According to the "Kojiki," Inahi no mikoto entered into the sea toward Kana no kuni Country, that is to say, toward the ocean.
sen.cmt: クォーテーション追加、全角スペースを半角に修正
sen.e: According to the "Kojiki," Inahi no mikoto entered into the sea toward Kana no kuni Country, that is to say, toward the ocean.

sen.j: 『日本書紀』では稲飯命は神武東征に従うが、熊野に進んで行くときに暴風に遭い、我が先祖は天神、母は海神であるのに、どうして我を陸に苦しめ、また海に苦しめるのか（「嗟乎 吾祖則天神 母則海神 如何厄我於陸 復厄我於海乎」）と行って、剣を抜いて海に入り、鋤持（サヒモチ）の神になったとする。
sen.e: On the other hand, according to the Nihonshoki, Inahi no mikoto went across the sea with Emperor Jinmu's troops to subdue the east region, but when he was attacked by a storm on the way to Kumano, he railed, '[m]y ancestors were Tenjin (heavenly gods) and my mother was Watatsumi no kami (tutelary of the sea), and yet why on earth you want to torment me, not only on the land but also in the sea?' and he entered the sea drawing a sword, and turned into Sahimochi no kami (deity Sahimochi).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。 我が先祖は天神、母は海神であるのに、どうして我を陸に苦しめ、また海に苦しめるのか（「嗟乎 吾祖則天神 母則海神 如何厄我於陸 復厄我於海乎」→定訳不明：'My ancestors were Tenjin (heavenly gods) and my mother was Watatsumi no kami (tutelary of the sea), and yet why on earth you want to torment me, not only on the land but also in the sea?' としました。
sen.e: On the other hand, according to the "Nihonshoki," Inahi no mikoto went across the sea with Emperor Jinmu's troops to subdue the east region, but when he was attacked by a storm on the way to Kumano, he railed, 'My ancestors were Tenjin (heavenly gods) and my mother was Watatsumi no kami (tutelary of the sea), and yet why on earth you want to torment me, not only on the land but also in the sea?' and he entered the sea drawing a sword, and turned into Sahimochi no kami (deity Sahimochi).

On the other hand, according to the "Nihonshoki," Inahi no mikoto went across the sea with Emperor Jinmu's troops to subdue the east region, but when he was attacked by a storm on the way to Kumano, he railed, 'My ancestors were Tenjin (heavenly gods) and my mother was Watatsumi no kami (tutelary of the sea), and yet why on earth you want to torment me, not only on the land but also in the sea?' and he entered the sea drawing a sword, and turned into Sahimochi no kami (deity Sahimochi).

sen.j: 鋤持とは鰐（ワニ）、鯱（シャチ）のことと言う。
sen.e: It is said that Sahimochi means 'wani' (shark) or 'shachi' (killer whale).
It is said that Sahimochi means 'wani' (shark) or 'shachi' (killer whale).
It is said that Sahimochi means 'wani' (shark) or 'shachi' (killer whale).

sen.j: 『古事記』にある山幸彦と海幸彦の神話に、海神宮から葦原中国に帰る火遠理命（ホオリ 山佐知毘古（山幸彦））を送った一尋和邇（一尋鰐）が、その御礼に、火遠理命が身に付けていた紐小刀を鰐魚の首につけてもらったので、この一尋和邇を、今謂う佐比持神(さひもちのかみ)とある。
sen.e: In the myth of 'Yamasachihiko and Umisachihiko' compiled in the Kojiki, there is an anecdote: Hitohiro-wani (Hitohiro shark) accompanied Hoori no mikoto (known as Yamasachihiko) on the way back to Ashihara no nakatsukuni (literally 'Central Land of Reed Plains,' which refers to the country or location of Japan) from Watatsumi no miya (the palace of the tutelary of the sea), and on parting with each other, Hoori no mikoto gave Hitohiro-wani (literally 'shark of 1.818m,' as 'hitohiro' is a unit of length equivalent to 6-shaku or 1.818m) a knife with a string, which he had carried with him, and hanged it to the neck of Hitohiro-wani, to express his gratitude, therefore, Hitohiro-wani became the deity currently known Sahimochi no kami.
sen.cmt: 一尋和邇→Hitohiro-wani (literally 'shark of 1.818m, as hitohiro is a unit of length equivalent to 6-shaku or 1.818m)大きさを示すために（）内の説明を加えました。
sen.e: In the myth of 'Yamasachihiko and Umisachihiko' compiled in the "Kojiki," there is an anecdote: Hitohiro-wani (Hitohiro shark) accompanied Hoori no mikoto (known as Yamasachihiko) on the way back to Ashihara no nakatsukuni (literally 'Central Land of Reed Plains,' which refers to the country or location of Japan) from Watatsumi no miya (the palace of the tutelary of the sea), and on parting with each other, Hoori no mikoto gave Hitohiro-wani (literally 'shark of 1.818m,' as 'hitohiro' is a unit of length equivalent to 6-shaku or 1.818m) a knife with a string, which he had carried with him, and hung it to the neck of Hitohiro-wani, to express his gratitude, therefore, Hitohiro-wani became the deity currently known Sahimochi no kami.
sen.cmt: Kojikiにクォーテーション追加、余分なスペース消去 hanged→hungに修正
sen.e: In the myth of 'Yamasachihiko and Umisachihiko' compiled in the "Kojiki," there is an anecdote: Hitohiro-wani (Hitohiro shark) accompanied Hoori no mikoto (known as Yamasachihiko) on the way back to Ashihara no nakatsukuni (literally 'Central Land of Reed Plains,' which refers to the country or location of Japan) from Watatsumi no miya (the palace of the tutelary of the sea), and on parting with each other, Hoori no mikoto gave Hitohiro-wani (literally 'shark of 1.818m,' as 'hitohiro' is a unit of length equivalent to 6-shaku or 1.818m) a knife with a string, which he had carried with him, and hung it to the neck of Hitohiro-wani, to express his gratitude, therefore, Hitohiro-wani became the deity currently known Sahimochi no kami.

sen.j: つまり、鰐となって母の国海神の国へ行ったということであろう。
sen.e: This story means that Inahi no mikoto transformed into a wani (shark) and went down to his mother's country, country of Watatsumi (tutelary of the sea).
This story means that Inahi no mikoto transformed into a wani (shark) and went down to his mother's country, country of Watatsumi (tutelary of the sea).
This story means that Inahi no mikoto transformed into a wani (shark) and went down to his mother's country, country of Watatsumi (tutelary of the sea).

sen.j: 玉依姫の姉、伯母のトヨタマビメの正体は、八尋和邇であった。
sen.e: The true identity of his aunt Princess Toyotamabime, who was Princess Tamayoribime (his mother) 's elder sister, was Yatsuhiro-wani (deity with a figure of more than 9m shark).
sen.cmt: 八尋和邇→定訳不明：Yatsuhiro-wani (deity with a figure of more than 9m shark) と（）内の説明を加えました。
sen.e: The true identity of his aunt Princess Toyotamabime, who was Princess Tamayoribime (his mother) 's older sister, was Yatsuhiro-wani (deity with a figure of more than 9m shark).
sen.cmt: elder sister→older sisterとし、余分なスペース消去
sen.e: The true identity of his aunt Princess Toyotamabime, who was Princess Tamayoribime (his mother) 's older sister, was Yatsuhiro-wani (deity with a figure of more than 9m shark).

sen.j: 『古事記』と『日本書紀』の話は対応している。
sen.e: In this way, the story about him in the Kojiki corresponds to that of the Nihonshoki.
In this way, the story about him in the "Kojiki" corresponds to that of the "Nihonshoki."
sen.cmt: クォーテーション追加
sen.e: In this way, the story about him in the "Kojiki" corresponds to that of the "Nihonshoki."

sen.j: また『新撰姓氏録』右京皇別下新良貴条は、「是出於新良国 即為国主 稲飯命出於新羅国王者組合」とあり稲飯命は新羅王の祖であるとする異説を載せている。
sen.e: On the other hand, in the section of 'Ukyokobetsunoge shirakunokudari' of "Shinsen Shojiroku (Newly Compiled Register of Clan Names and Titles of Nobility), there can be found a different theory arguing as 'Inahi no mikoto was the founder and the first King of Silla (ancient Korean kingdom).'
sen.cmt: 「是出於新良国 即為国主 稲飯命出於新羅国王者組合 」とあり稲飯命は新羅王の祖である→定訳不明：'Inahi no mikoto was the founder and the first King of Silla (ancient Korean kingdom)' としました。
sen.e: On the other hand, in the section of 'Ukyokobetsunoge shirakunokudari' of "Shinsen Shojiroku" (Newly Compiled Register of Clan Names and Titles of Nobility), there can be found a different theory arguing as 'Inahi no mikoto was the founder and the first King of Silla (ancient Korean kingdom).'
sen.cmt: クォーテーションの位置を移動
sen.e: On the other hand, in the section of 'Ukyokobetsunoge shirakunokudari' of "Shinsen Shojiroku" (Newly Compiled Register of Clan Names and Titles of Nobility), there can be found a different theory arguing as 'Inahi no mikoto was the founder and the first King of Silla (ancient Korean kingdom).'

sen.j: （朝鮮の歴史書『三国史記』新羅本紀・脱解尼師今紀では、「脱解本多婆那國所生也 其國在倭國東北一千里」とあり新羅の4代目の王にして昔氏王統の初代である脱解尼師今は倭国の東北千里にある本多婆那國の出であるとされており、関連性が見られる）。
sen.e: ('Silla History' and 'Dakkai Nishikin-ki [Chronicle of Dakkai Nishikin] in a Korean history book "Samguk Sagi "[History of the Three Kingdoms] indicates a certain relation with this theory, writing that Dakkai Nishikin is 'the forth King of Silla and the first generation of the Seki clan of the King's bloodline, who was from Tabana-koku Country situated in a distance of one thousand-ri [about 4,000 km] to the northeast of Wakoku [Japan]).
sen.cmt: 脱解尼師今紀→定訳不明： 'Dakkai Nishikin-ki （Chronicle of Dakkai Nishikin） （）内を加えました。 「脱解本多婆那國所生也 其國在倭國東北一千里」とあり新羅の4代目の王にして昔氏王統の初代である脱解尼師今は倭国の東北千里にある本多婆那國の出である→定訳不明：'Dakkai Nishikin is 'the forth King of Silla and the first generation of the Seki clan of the King's bloodline, who was from Tabana-koku Country situated in a distance of one thousand-ri (about 4,000 km) to the northeast of Wakoku (Japan) としました。
sen.e: ('Silla History' and 'Dakkai Nishikin-ki' [Chronicle of Dakkai Nishikin] in a Korean history book "Samguk Sagi"[History of the Three Kingdoms] indicates a certain relation with this theory, writing that Dakkai Nishikin is the forth King of Silla and the first generation of the Seki clan of the King's bloodline, who was from Tabana-koku Country situated in a distance of one thousand-ri [about 4,000 km] to the northeast of Wakoku [Japan]).
sen.cmt: クォーテーション表記修正、余分なスペース消去
sen.e: ('Silla History' and 'Dakkai Nishikin-ki' [Chronicle of Dakkai Nishikin] in a Korean history book "Samguk Sagi"[History of the Three Kingdoms] indicates a certain relation with this theory, writing that Dakkai Nishikin is the forth King of Silla and the first generation of the Seki clan of the King's bloodline, who was from Tabana-koku Country situated in a distance of one thousand-ri [about 4,000 km] to the northeast of Wakoku [Japan]).
